case_name: Samant N. Balakrishna and S. K. Patil v. George Fernandez

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 895 and 896 of 1968 were filed under Section 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 895 and 896 of 1968. Appeals under S. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated January 29, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Election Petition No. 6 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated January 29, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Election Petition No. 6 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 895 and 896 of 1968. Appeals under S. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated January 29, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Election Petition No. 6 of 1967.

facts.text: In the last General Election to Parliament from the Bombay South Parliamentary constituency, eight candidates contested.

anchor.surface_text: In the last General Election to Parliament from the Bombay South Parliamentary companystituency eight candidates had offered themselves.

facts.text: George Fernandez secured 1,47,841 votes as against his nearest rival S.K. Patil who secured 1,18,407 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The answering respondent Mr.George Fernandez secured 1,47,841 votes as against his nearest rival Mr. S.K. Patil who secured 1,18,407 votes. The remaining candidates secured a few thousand votes between them.

facts.text: Result of the poll was declared on February 24, 1967, and George Fernandez was returned.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining candidates secured a few thousand votes between them. The result of the poll was declared on February 24, 1967. and Mr. George Fernandez was returned.

facts.text: Election petition was filed by Samant N. Balakrishna, an elector in the constituency, challenging the election of George Fernandez.

anchor.surface_text: An election petition was filed by Mr. Samant N. Balakrishna, an elector in the companystituency. It challenged the election of Mr. Fernandez and was ostensibly in the interest of Mr. S. K. Patil.

facts.text: Election petition was filed on April 7, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: This was the original material on which the petition filed on April 7, 1967 was based.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed the election petition with costs against the election petitioner and S.K. Patil.

anchor.surface_text: The election petition failed and it was dismissed with an order for companyts against the election petitioner and Mr. S. K. Patil. Two appeals have number been filed against the judgment of the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Two appeals filed against Bombay High Court judgment: one by election petitioner, one by S.K. Patil.

anchor.surface_text: Two appeals have number been filed against the judgment of the Bombay High Court, one by the election petitioner and the other by Mr. S. K. Patil. They have been heard together and this judgment will dispose of both of them.

facts.text: Petition based on grounds A to J in paragraph 2, with A to D given up in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was based on numerous grounds which were, set out in paragraph 2 of the petition. These grounds were shown separately in sub-paragraphs A to J. Sub-paragraphs A to D dealt with the invalidity of the election for number- companypliance with s, 62 of the Representation of the People Act and Arts. 326 and 327 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Sub-paragraphs E to J contained allegations of corrupt practices, accompanied by annexures A to D from newspapers.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-paragraphs E to J companytained allegations of companyrupt practices. The petition was accompanied by four annexures Nos. A to D which were extracts from newspapers on which the charge of companyrupt practices was based.

facts.text: George Fernandez filed written statement on June 14, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Fernandez filed his written statement on June 14, 1967 and Mr. S. K. Patil on July 4, 1967.

facts.text: S.K. Patil filed written statement on July 4, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Fernandez filed his written statement on June 14, 1967 and Mr. S. K. Patil on July 4, 1967.

facts.text: Five amendments were asked for to the petition.

anchor.surface_text: Later five amendments were asked for.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that originals of newspaper exhibits A to D were not filed with the petition but later.

anchor.surface_text: The Rozana- mas clearly show that the companyies of the Maratha were number filed with the election petition but much later and in fact beyond the period of limitation.

facts.text: Supreme Court disallowed amendments introducing new corrupt practices by Fernandez personally after limitation period.

anchor.surface_text: At the companyclusion of the arguments on this part of the case we announced our decision that the amendment relating to the speeches of Mr. Fernandez at Shivaji Park, Sabu Siddik Chowk and Dr. Vigas Street and his Press Conferences at Bristol Grill Restaurant and the article in the Blitz ought number to have been allowed

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed amendment alleging agency of Maratha, Shankaracharya, and Madhu Limaye for Fernandez.

anchor.surface_text: but that the amendment relating to the agency of the Maratha etc. and that seeking to incorporate the averment about the lack of belief of Mr. Fernandez were proper.

facts.text: Bombay High Court trial judge held Acharya Atrey acted as agent of Fernandez.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge was also satisfied that Mr. Atrey companyld be held to have acted as the agent of Mr. Fernandez.

facts.text: Respondent's counsel conceded Atrey could be treated as agent of Fernandez.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari for Mr. Fernandez companyceded the position that Mr. Atrey companyld be treated as the agent of Mr. Fernandez.

facts.text: Petition alleged corrupt practices under sections 123(3), 123(3A), 123(4) based on speeches and Maratha publications.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-paragraph E dealt with statements made at a meeting dated February 16, 1967 at Shivaji Park by Jagadguru Shankaracharya charging Mr. S. K. Patil with companyplicity in arson of November 7, 1966 at New Delhi...

facts.text: Originals of Maratha issues filed on July 7, 1967, after limitation period.

anchor.surface_text: On July 7, 1967 the Rozanaina read as follows Mr. Gurushani tenders the original of the exhibits A  Coll  to Exhibit E  Coll  mentioned in para 2J of page 1 1 of the petition.

facts.text: Evidence commenced on August 25, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The first witness to be examined was the petitioner himself. Evidence companymenced on August 25, 1967.

facts.text: Petitioner proved copies of newspapers marked as exhibits.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner proved the companyies of the newspapers and they were marked as exhibits.

issues.text: the question of the amendments and whether they were properly allowed

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with this appeal it is necessary to clear the question of the amendments and whether they were properly allowed. This question consists of two parts the first is one of fact as to what was exhibited with the petition as materials on which the petition was based.

issues.text: Whether such an amendment is allowable under the Election Law

anchor.surface_text: Whether such an amendment is allowable under the Election Law is therefore necessary to decide. Mr. Daphtary arguing for the appellant contends that he was entitled to the amendment since this was no more than an amplification of the ground of corrupt practice as defined in S. 123(4) and that the citation of instances or giving of additional parti-

issues.text: what was the corrupt practice is limited to what was said in the body of the petition in paragraph 2J and whether it could be amended after the period of limitation was over

anchor.surface_text: We have to reach this conclusion first because once we hold that the issues of the Maratha or the extracts referred to in the petition were not filed, the plea as to what was the corrupt practice is limited to what was said in the body of the petition in paragraph 2J and whether it could be amended after the period of limitation was over.

issues.text: whether Mr. Atrey had the consent of Mr. Fernandez to the publications in his newspaper

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore necessary to pause here to decide, whether Mr. Atrey had the consent of Mr. Fernandez to the publications in his newspaper. The difference between Mr. Daphtarys contention and that of Mr. Jethmalani lies in this.

issues.text: Whether the Maratha acted as agent of Mr. Fernandez with his consent for the purpose of publishing false statements

anchor.surface_text: The case as originally pleaded fell within s. 100(1)(d) with the additional burden. anchor.surface_text: From this case it follows that to prove a corrupt practice in an agent is not enough, the belief of the candidate himself must be investigated with a view to finding out whether he made a statement which he knew to be false or did not believe to be true.

holdings.text: The Rozanamas clearly show that the copies of the Maratha were not filed with the election petition but much later and in fact beyond the period of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The Rozanamas clearly show that the copies of the Maratha were not filed with the election petition but much later and in fact beyond the period of limitation. Mr. Daphtary characterises the Rozanamas as inaccurate but the internal evidence in the case shows that the Rozanamas were correctly recorded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rozanamas and office records confirm copies filed post-limitation; internal evidence supports accuracy; no waiver despite lack of early objection.

holdings.text: Once issues of the Maratha or extracts not filed, plea as to corrupt practice limited to body of petition in paragraph 2J and cannot be amended after limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We have to reach this conclusion first because once we hold that the issues of the Maratha or the extracts referred to in the petition were not filed, the plea as to what was the corrupt practice is limited to what was said in the body of the petition in paragraph 2J and whether it could be amended after the period of limitation was over.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of timely filing restricts scope to pleaded text; post-limitation amendments cannot expand corrupt practice allegations.

holdings.text: Amendment relating to speeches of Mr. Fernandez at Shivaji Park, Sabu Siddik Chowk, Dr. Vigas Street, Press Conferences at Bristol Grill and Blitz article ought not to have been allowed.

anchor.surface_text: At the conclusion of the arguments on this part of the case we announced our decision that the amendment relating to the speeches of Mr. Fernandez at Shivaji Park, Sabu Siddik Chowk and Dr. Vigas Street and his Press Conferences at Bristol Grill Restaurant and the article in the Blitz ought not to have been allowed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Introduces new corrupt practices by candidate personally not alleged originally; constitutes new cause of action barred post-limitation under s.86(5).

holdings.text: Amendment relating to agency of Maratha etc. and averment about lack of belief of Mr. Fernandez proper.

anchor.surface_text: but that the amendment relating to the agency of the Maratha etc. and that seeking to incorporate the averment about the lack of belief of Mr. Fernandez were proper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Completes existing cause of action under Order VI r.17; amplifies particulars without new corrupt practice.

holdings.text: Material facts necessary to formulate complete cause of action must be stated; particulars amplify to give full picture.

anchor.surface_text: What is the difference between material facts and particulars? The word material shows that the facts necessary to formulate a complete cause of action must be stated. Omission of a single material fact leads to an incomplete cause of action and the statement of claim becomes bad.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory mandate in s.83 distinguishes: material facts state cause, particulars detail; omission defective petition.

holdings.text: s.86(5) allows amendment/amplification of particulars of alleged corrupt practice but not introducing new corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (5) of that section provides The High Court may... allow the particulars of any corrupt practice alleged in the petition to be amended or amplified... but shall not allow any amendment of the petition which will have the effect of introducing particulars of a corrupt practice not previously alleged in the petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual bar on new practices; enabling for particulars only; strict election law compliance.

holdings.text: Under s.100(1)(d), corrupt practice by agent other than election agent requires proof result materially affected.

anchor.surface_text: d that the result of the election, in so far as it concerns a returned candidate, has been materially affected... by any corrupt practice committed in the interests

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory distinction: no such proof needed for candidate/election agent/with consent; additional burden for other agents.

holdings.text: For s.123(4), candidate's belief in falsity required even if publication by agent.

anchor.surface_text: From this case it follows that to prove a corrupt practice in an agent is not enough, the belief of the candidate himself must be investigated with a view to finding out whether he made a statement which he knew to be false or did not believe to be true.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent (Kumara Nand): 'he' refers to candidate; mens rea element personal.

holdings.text: Mr. Atrey could be held to have acted as agent of Mr. Fernandez.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge was also satisfied that Mr. Atrey could be held to have acted as the agent of Mr. Fernandez.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge finding; respondent concession accepts agency.

holdings.text: No consent of Mr. Fernandez to specific publications by Atrey/Maratha.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore necessary to pause here to decide, whether Mr. Atrey had the consent of Mr. Fernandez to the publications in his newspaper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agency does not presume consent to each act; no evidence of specific consent or material effect; distinction s.100(1)(b)/(d).
